captions.text:
- [Voiceover] This is master
wurstmacher, Adam Gertler,

and culinary director,
Michael Brown from Dog Hous.

Together, they created the
craziest hot dogs possible.

The hot dogs you'll see
today are not on the menu
and are exclusive to BuzzFeed.

- These sausages are
experimental in nature.

Some of them will and
should never be made again.
("Blast Funk")

This one is a shrimp and
jumbo lump crab meat sausage.
The base is a puree of shrimp
with a little bit of garlic,
kind of an Old Bay style seasoning,
some fresh lemon zest, lemon juice,
large jumbo lump crab meat.

- So I'm gonna show
you what we're gonna do
with Adam's sausages,

and how we're gonna
present them for you guys.
Take this nice grilled seafood sausage,
purple potatoes, carrots, and corn.

I made an aioli with
Chesapeake Bay seasoning.
And there you have it,
this is the Wicked Pissa.
- Is this supposed to be sushi?
- It still smells like sausage.
- Yep.
- Holy (bleep).
- A fancy version of a fish stick.
- Maybe a little too salty for my tastes,
but it's still pretty,
I'm just gonna eat more.
("Blast Funk")

- A Vietnamese style
pork influenced sausages.
So it's all pork, cilantro, mint,
scallions, fish sauce, shallot.
We're doing it as more of a banh mi
and we're calling it our Banh Appetit.
- Just a little bit of hoisin sauce,
pickled vegetable mixture,
green lime mayonnaise.

And there you have it,
that's Banh Appetit.
- I'm really excited about this.
I love Vietnamese sandwiches.

- I think that there's
maybe a missed opportunity
to put this on French bread.
- It tastes like a very unhealthy banh mi.
- This actually tastes like

one of the more healthier
hot dogs I've ever had.

- It does taste a little
bit like a banh mi.
- This is my least favorite right now,

but still a 10 out of
10 and would eat again.
("Blast Funk")
- Duck, chicken, and turkey,
and put it inside of a sort of like a
kielbasa style sausage.
So there's fresh thyme in there,
lots of fresh garlic, onions.
And then the sausage was smoked.
- We've lightly wilted some pea tendrils
with the foie gras fat.
Onions, balsamic, and fig,
and we've reduced that down to like a jam.
Generously seasoned the foie gras.
We're gonna top that off.
Brown butter toasted hazelnuts
give it a little bit of crunch.
That's the menage a foie.
- This is a sexy mother (bleep) hot dog.
- Oh!
Oh!
- Yes, 10 out of 10 would eat again.
- It's definitely like more in line

with what I imagined
like a brat tastes like.
- It's sweet on top.
It's tangy inside.
- Everything is so good together.
I don't understand what's happening.
("Blast Funk")
- I give you the Surf and Turfwurst.
What you have is excellent quality
Maine lobster tail
and ribeye steak in a sausage form.

- I'm gonna put a little bit
of wild arugula in there.
Just gonna ladle a little bearnaise over.
Crispy fried parsnip chips.
And that is your Surf and Turf.

- This is like something
that Willy Wonka would make.

- This may be the first
one I'm not that into.
- It's so good.
- This is lobster?
- This is a luxury dog.
I should be wearing a tuxedo right now,
but I forgot it at home.
("Blast Funk")

- Fried chicken is such an
American down home classic.

How could it have possibly
have taken this long

for us to come up with
a fried chicken sausage?

But that's exactly what
we did for Buzz Feed.
We basically took the classic
southern fried chicken flavors.

I'm talking about your
buttermilk marinade,
your fresh thyme, your garlic,

your mustard powder, your
cayenne pepper, salt, pepper.
We put all that inside the sausage.

We're using a little bit
of a vodka beer batter.
And then we're gonna fry the chicken
and then serve it with a waffle.
- [Michael] Sweet maple and buttermilk
kinda coleslaw dressing.
Pull that string out.
With a little drizzle of honey.
Your fried chicken and waffle sausage.
- This looks like the most American thing
that I've ever seen.
- It's like a warm hug.
- This is amazing.

- Always fry sausages,
this is what I've learned.
- This is the best thing I've eaten today,

and maybe like will for
the rest of my life.
("Blast Funk")
- I was thinking oh my God,

I can't believe I'm
making dessert sausage.
That's so disgusting.
Why would anyone do that?
And I started drinking,
and then I thought,

you know what, why don't I
just put that in the sausage.
So we have kind of an Irish car bomb
influence in the sausage.
Cinnamon, nutmeg, all spice, maple syrup.
And then we finished it off
with dark chocolate and marshmallow.
- Ooey gooey, fun in this thing here.
Brown butter pecan sauce.
Beautiful caramelized bananas.
The Wurst Dessert.
- Time for dessert.
- OK, this isn't...
- What?
- What?
- There's meat in this?
- It does kinda taste like s'mores,
as weird as that sounds.

- I'm gonna be telling my
grandchildren about this (bleep).
- You can hot dog dessert.
Proof.
("Blast Funk")

comments.author: FoxyWhite

comments.text:
+Charles Black I eat steak from local farms where the cows lived proper, 
healthy, stress free lives, and I only endorse others to do the same. Soooo
comments.author: FoxyWhite

comments.text:
+Chloe Coleman well that is a non sequitur and follows nothing on the 
argument at hand. If we had the ability to donate my appendix with out any 
invasive procedure on me and for it to be able to feed someone who had no 
problem with cannibalistic tendencies, then i'd be all for it. But again 
that has nothing to do with the argument and is in the end my personal 
prerogative.
comments.author: Charles Black

comments.text:
+Charles Black We've evolved not to really need our appendix. Are you cool 
with having that taken out for someone to eat? Its just exploiting an 
evolutionary trait after all....
comments.author: Chloe Coleman

comments.text:
+FoxyWhite Dude, my whole point is that these are different species with 
different physiological traits. You cannot compare the force feeding of 
most mammalian species to the force feeding of fowl, because most mammals 
did not evolve to a) have no gag reflex (i.e. they puke) or b) to have 
organs developed to store large quantities of fat to survive long trek 
migration. Ducks and geese on the other hand evolved to have these 
characteristics. Foie gras producers exploit these evolutionary 
characteristics to produce foie as well as geese meat. So it is no 
different than, eating a steak which will come from a slaughter house.
comments.author: Charles Black

comments.text:
+Charles Black Do you want to be force fed? Would you force feed a dog or a 
cat until their stomachs just about burst? No? Then how about you not do it 
to ducks and geese.
comments.author: FoxyWhite

comments.text:
+Chloe Coleman while it is a cop out excuse, the heart of the matter is 
wether we can categorize force-feeding of ducks and geese as cruel and 
torturous. We are talking about animals who have evolved to store as much 
fat as possible for migratory purposes, particularly on its liver, and has 
no gag reflex in order to swallow everything it can. While it might seem 
cruel if you anthropomorphize these animals, the fact of the matter is that 
it is very different. Please watch that brief documentary I posted above, 
it has a very unbiased approach of the whole issue.
comments.author: Charles Black

comments.text:
+wafflenuno Thats a weak, cop out excuse. You're supporting the cruelty. 
You're doing a weird form of contract killing except you're also ordering 
the victim to be tortured first. You're so weak and selfish.
comments.author: Chloe Coleman

comments.text:
+FoxyWhite I know it's cruel, but I also eat foie gras because: even if I 
don't like foie gras or eat it on a daily basis it's not gonna stop the 
people from making it. So you might as well eat it because, after all, foie 
gras is still gonna be produced at the end of the day
comments.author: wafflenuno

comments.text:
+Charles Black Do you know what foie gras even is? It's not JUST liver. 
It's from a bird that was force fed until their stomachs burst. It's 
monstrously inhumane.
comments.author: FoxyWhite

comments.text:
+FoxyWhite not if you get free range. those geese can run and have free 
space and treated humanely.
